question: (scip) #### sceal genægled⁠ — A ship must be nailed
explanation: Here 'scip' is the subject and so takes no ending

question: Ðæs cyninges (word) #### is soþ⁠ — The king's word is truth
explanation: Here 'word' is the subject and so takes no ending

question: Godes (bearn) #### þrowode on þære rode⁠ — God's son suffered on the cross
explanation: Here 'bearn' is the subject and so takes no ending

question: Ðæt (wif) #### wæs gehæled of ðæm wite⁠ — The woman was healed of the disease
explanation: Here 'wif' is the subject and so takes no ending

question: Hiora (god) #### sindon drycræfta lareowas⁠ — Their gods are teachers of magical arts
explanation: Here 'god' is the subject and plural, so since 'god' has a short syllable it takes a 'u' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Here 'god' is the subject and plural, but since 'god' has a short syllable it should take a 'u' ending

question: Ða (scip) #### þara wicinga comon on þissum dæg⁠e — The Vikings' ships came on this day
explanation: Here 'scip' is the subject and plural, so since 'scip' has a short syllable it takes a 'u' ending

question: Gif þa (word) #### sind soþ⁠e — If the words are true
explanation: Here 'word' is the subject and plural, so since 'word' has a long syllable it takes no ending

question: Geata (bearn) #### ferdon to him⁠ — The children of the Geats went to him
explanation: Here 'bearn' is the subject and plural, so since 'bearn' has a long syllable it takes no ending

question: Seo geofu wæs broht for ðære synne ðæs ærestan (wif) ####⁠ — The grace was brought for the sin of the first woman
explanation: Here 'wif' is in the genitive singular, so it takes the 'es' ending

question: He wæs hiora (god) #### preost⁠ — He was the priest of their god
explanation: Here 'god' is in the genitive singular, so it takes the 'es' ending

question: Þæs (scip) #### mæst w⁠æs gebornen — The ship's mast was burned
explanation: Here 'scip' is in the genitive singular, so it takes the 'es' ending

question: Þæt þurh (bearn) #### gebyrd butan weres frigum, bryd eacen wearð⁠ — Through the bearing of a child without a man's embrace, that bride became great
explanation: Here 'bearn' is in the genitive singular, so it takes the 'es' ending

question: Seo is sæd ærest þara (wif) #### in Norþanhymbra mægþe ðæt heo munuchade onfenge⁠ — She is said to have been one of the first women in Northumbria to have taken nun-hood
explanation: Here 'wif' is in the genitive plural, so it takes the 'a' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Here 'wif' is in the genitive plural as she is 'one of the first', so it takes the 'a' ending

question: On þis dæge, com þæs hæthenes (god) #### wigan⁠ — On that day, the warriors of the heathen gods came
explanation: Here 'god' is in the genitive plural, so it takes the 'a' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Here 'god' is in the genitive plural, so it takes the 'a' ending, not the singular 'es' ending

question: Ða het se cyning (scip) #### gegearcian⁠ — Then the king ordered the preparation of ships
explanation: Here 'scip' is in the genitive plural, so it takes the 'a' ending

question: Hlosna to þæs Godes (word) ####⁠ — Listen to the word of God
explanation: Here 'word' is in the singular accusative, and so takes no ending

question: He Noe gebletsade ond his (bearn) ####⁠ — He blessed Noah and his child
explanation: Here 'bearn' is in the singular accusative, and so takes no ending

question: He spræc to þæm (wif) ####⁠ — He spoke to the woman
explanation: Here 'wif' is in the singular dative, and so takes the 'e' ending

question: Ðu bigongest fremede (god) #### ⁠fram Egipta lande — You worship strange gods from Egypt
explanation: Here 'god' is the direct object and plural, so since 'god' has a short syllable it takes a 'u' ending

question: He wolde geseean helle (god) ####⁠ — he would visit the gods of hell
explanation: Here 'god' is the direct object and plural, so since 'god' has a short syllable it takes a 'u' ending

question: Ða wæron þa erestan (scip) #### Deniscra manna þe Angelcynnes land geseah⁠ — Those were the first ships of Danish men that the English people's land saw
explanation: Here 'scip' is the direct object and plural, so since 'god' has a short syllable it takes a 'u' ending

question: Hie writon micel (word) #### lofa⁠ — They wrote many words of praise
explanation: Here 'word' is the direct object and plural, so since 'word' has a long syllable it takes no ending

question: Se fæder wið-soc eall to his (bearn) ####⁠ — The father denied all to his child
explanation: Here 'bearn' is the indirect object and singular, and so takes an 'e' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Here 'bearn' is the indirect object and singular, and so takes an 'e' ending. It is 'eall' which is the direct object

question: And mon mot feohtan orwige gif he gemeteþ oðerne æt his æwum (wif) ####⁠ — And a man can fight without charge of homicide if he finds another with his lawful wife
explanation: Here 'wif' is the indirect object and singular, and so takes an 'e' ending

question: Seo cwen geaf þa boc to þæm ####⁠ — The queen gave the book to the woman
explanation: Here 'wif' is the indirect object and singular, and so takes an 'e' ending

question: We willaþ mid þæm sceattum us to þæm (scip) #### gangan⁠ — We wish to go to the ship with the treasure
explanation: Here 'scip' is the indirect object and singular, and so takes an 'e' ending

question: He ærest sceop eorþan for his (bearn) ####⁠ — He first shaped the earth for his children
explanation: Here 'bearn' is the indirect object and plural, and so takes a 'um' ending

question: Heo geaf micel giefa to þæm (wif) ####⁠ — She gave many gifts to the women
explanation: Here 'wif' is the indirect object and plural, and so takes a 'um' ending

question: Hie bædon to hiora (god) ####⁠ — They prayed to their gods
explanation: Here 'god' is the indirect object and plural, and so takes a 'um' ending

question: Se here ferde to þæm (scip) ####⁠ — The army went to the ships
explanation: Here 'scip' is the indirect object and plural, and so takes a 'um' ending
